With income from maize sales, Josephine will educate her children and build a house. In 2012, the members of Baraka C group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

For 10 years, Cherry has had a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy more of these products for her store.

Cherry has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Phylice

texts.en:
Phylice is a 44 year-old modest lady from Mugen area of Vihiga county, Western Kenya. She is married to Jackson, a livestock trader, and they have five children.

Phylice is a farmer and has specialized in small scale maize farming, a business she has done for the last one year. She joined KADET LTD and has been awarded a first loan of KES 30,000 which she will use to buy fertilizer and other farm inputs.  

She intends to use the profits to repay the loan and also improve her family living standards. Her dream is to continue sustaining her business so that she has stable income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a twenty-five year-old lady from Mugen area of Vihiga County, Western Kenya. She is married to Nicholas, and they have two children. 

Jackline operates a retail shop in Mugen Centre, a business she has done for the last one year.  She recently joined KADET LTD and has applied for a first loan which she will use to buy her retail stock like sugar, cooking oil, soap, and many other items.  

She will use the profits to stock more goods and also purchase dairy cows as part of diversification to dairy farming. Her dream is to expand her business through KADET funding.

loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking fat, and other retail stock.

loans.name: Marianita

texts.en:
Marianita is from Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old. Marianita is a widow and has four grown-up children. 

To make a living, Marianita owns and operates a business selling clothes and shoes to the local community. Marianita has been in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,900 PHP a month.

Marianita is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items so she can expand the range of goods she sells.  

In 2008, Marianita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to expand the range of goods she sells.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 6 children. 

Tessie has a shop from which she sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, detergents & beverages.

Tessie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Tessie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, detergents & beverages.

loans.name: Mukhtar Bibi

texts.en:
Mukhtar bibi is a 36-year-old woman. She is married and lives with her family, a husband and four children, who are 16, 11, 8 and 6. Her husband is involved in rent-a-bike business. He lets his bikes out, on rent, and charges on an hourly basis. He has good demand among his customers, due to his good customer dealings and good conditions of the motor bikes. He has been involved in this business for over 10 years. 

Mukhtar bibi herself is also a very supportive lady. She owns & operates a sewing business at her home to supplement the income for her family. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients and charges PKRs 150 for normal stitching and PKRs 200 for designer dress. She uses her income to pay off the utilities.    

Mukhtar is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. Her husband intends to use the loan to purchase another motor bike and some spare parts for generating more revenue for his business. Mukhtar is hopeful that the loan investment will bring positive financial changes to the business and her family will use the increased income for their well-being.

loans.use: to buy another motorbike and spare parts for her husband's rent-a-bike business.

loans.name: Mwenda Pole Group

texts.en:
Benard  is the facilitator of the Mwenda Pole group. Benard  and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Benard  takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Benard  had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Benard was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Benard  and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Benard will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mwenda Pole group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Benard is pictured with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair water boreholes.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 39-year-old modest lady from Vihiga County, Western Kenya.  She is married to Noel and they have three kids.

Alice operates a dressmaking business where she designs clothing for men and women and also does tailoring work. She has been in this trade for the last four years and makes a monthly income of KES 15,000. She is taking her first loan from KADET LTD  which she will use to buy textiles.

She will use the profits to provide for her family and also to expand her business. Her hope is to sustain her business and ensure it expands.

loans.use: To buy textiles for dressmaking.
